Dear Ms. Prudhomme:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at, (616) 204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4160 Emergency restraint.
Section (1) The use of emergency restraint as a lifesaving response for a
Description youth will be limited to:
(a) An emergency response to protect the youth or others from
an unanticipated or severely aggressive behavior that places the
youth or others at serious threat of violence or injury if no
immediate intervention occurs.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was placed in a restraint by staff for throwing items and
grabbing a spatula. Another staff member was also involved in the
restraint. The restraint occurred on 6/17/2023 and was
unwarranted.
Investigation The complainant is this consultant as during review of an
incident report it was documented Youth A was restrained for
throwing items and grabbing a spatula.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 5,
2023. Youth A stated he was restrained in the kitchen because he
was, “doing wrong and unsafe things.” Youth A reported he
“sliced” Staff 2’s hand with a sharp spatula and tried to hit a youth
so he was restrained. Youth A denied getting injured in the
restraint and stated the restraint did not hurt. Youth A said, “I feel
staff should have placed me in a hold.” Youth A reported Staff 1
held Youth A’s arms and Staff 2 held Youth A’s legs in the
restraint. Youth A could not recall if other youth saw the restraint.
Youth A reported he could not recall other details because of the
medicine he takes.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 5,
2023. Youth B reported Youth A was arguing and threatening
peers, Staff 1, and Staff 2. Youth B stated Youth A began
throwing things in the kitchen area of the house, so Youth B went
outside to the swings to get away from the situation. Youth B
reported he did not see the restraint but heard Youth A was in a
restraint. Youth B stated he has seen staff restrain youth and
does not have any concerns about the restraints. Youth B
reported he likes it at the facility and feels safe.
2

Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 5,
2023. Youth C reported Youth A made a mess in the kitchen,
broke the TV, and took a spatula and cut Staff 2. Youth C stated,
“it was a proper restraint.” Youth C stated Staff 2 was bleeding
from the cut on his hand. Youth C described Staff 1 holding one
of Youth A arms and Staff 2 holding Youth A’s other arm. Youth C
stated Youth A was kicking so Staff 1 and Staff 2 moved Youth A
into a seated position. Youth C denied having any concerns with
the restraint. Youth C stated, “hell yeah they should have
restrained him(Youth A) for cutting Staff 2.”
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 5,
2023. Staff 1 described Youth A being upset because he was not
allowed to feed the fish because another youth had already feed
the fish. Staff 1 stated Youth A began to argue and threaten to hit
another youth and staff. Staff 1 reported dinner was being
prepared at this time and Youth A poured a gallon of milk on the
floor, threw the milk jug, then dumped the food that was ready for
dinner on the floor. Staff 1 stated Youth A picked up an easel and
hit the TV six times, cracking the TV screen. Staff 1 reported
Youth A picked up the spatula that was going to be used for
dinner, cut open a couch cushion with it and cut Staff 2’s hand
when Staff 2 attempted to get the spatula. Staff 1 stated he
initiated a benevolent hold at that time. Staff 1 reported Youth A
said Staff 1 was positioned wrong, so Staff 1 asked Staff 2 to
check the positioning. Staff 2 checked and said the positioning
was okay. Staff 1 stated Youth A was transitioned to a two person
hold with Staff 1 holding one arm and Staff 2 holding Youth A’s
other arm while Staff 1 continued with verbal de-escalation. Staff 1
reported the spatula is now locked up. Staff 1 stated he would not
have thought it should have been locked up because he did not
really think of it as being a sharp object. Staff 1 reported youth
use pots and pans to try and hit staff and maybe they should be
locked up as well. Staff 1 stated he felt the restraint was
warranted because Youth A cut Staff 2 with the spatula. Staff 1
reported Youth A was verbally threatening youth and staff when
Youth A had the easel and cracked the TV. Staff 1 described
Youth A as being very escalated.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on July 5,
2023. Staff 2 stated Youth A sliced Staff 2’s left hand between his
thumb and pointer finger when Staff 2 attempted to get the spatula
from Youth A. Staff 2 reported Youth A was restrained for the
“safety of others.” Staff 2 described Youth A threatening his
peers, throwing items at his peers, and grabbing a music standing
and breaking the TV.
3

Director of Quality and Compliance was interviewed face to
face at the facility on July 5, 2023. Director of Quality and
Compliance reported the incident report in MiSACWIS did not
include the entire narrative from the Eagle Village incident report
describing the incident with Youth A in its entirety. The narrative
was copied and pasted from the Eagle Village incident report but
left out the first two paragraphs describing Youth A’s behaviors
leading up to the restraint.
Documents Reviewed:
• Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Incident report 156900207 involving Youth A: Incident
report describes Youth A being placed in a restraint for
“throwing things again and grabbing a spatula.”
• Eagle Village Incident Report dated 6/17/2023 involving
Youth A: Incident report describes Youth A threatening to
cut his peers, grabbing a metal music stand smashing the
TV, breaking windows, and cutting Staff 2’s hand with a
spatula. This incident report is consistent with Youth A,
Youth C, Staff 1, and Staff 2’s interviews.
• Staff 1’s personnel file: There was one disciplinary record
not related to restraints and Staff 1 completed the required
Aegis training on 1/18/23.
• Staff 2’s personnel file: There was no disciplinary record
and Staff 2 completed the required Aegis training on 2/8/23.
Analysis The facility is found in compliance as the restraint was warranted
due to Youth A cutting Staff 2’s hand with a spatula. The incident
report I reviewed did not have the information describing the
events and Youth A’s behavior leading up to the restraint.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
Section (1) An institution shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures addressing all of the following:
(d) Storage of medications.
Violation Additional Findings of Non-Compliance
Type
Allegation The medication cart was unlocked and the door where the
medication is kept was unlocked. The staff office door was
locked.
Investigation I completed a walkthrough of Gerber House on July 5, 2023.
Upon entering the medication office, the door was observed to be
slightly opened, unlocked and the medication cart unlocked. The
4

staff office door leading to the medication room was locked.
There were no youth in the house at the time.
Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the facility on July
5, 2023. Supervisor stated it was “crazy” at the house when
leaving that morning and locking the medication cart was
forgotten. Supervisor showed me that he had the medication keys
in his pocket. Supervisor stated the medication cart being
unlocked would have been noticed when returning to the house or
for sure when the keys were passed to the next staff member.
Documents Reviewed:
• Residential Services Standard Operating Procedures,
Residential Storage of Medication: Policy states, “All
medication shall be stored in the locked medication cart.
This locked cart will be placed in a location within each
residence that is an area restricted to residents and that
requires entrance through one locked door.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as the medication cart was
left unlocked.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
